review_blob: Bottle. Clear orange color with thin, pale, sudsy head leaving light lacing. Some iridescence in the bubbles. Strong hops scent, some pine & citrus aromas. Hoptastic flavor, nice bitter bite, a little detergent astringency, very little malt profile. Much more bubbly and effervescent than I expected. Clean dry finish. Reminds me a bit of a Lagunitas IPA. Pleasant and smooth-drinking, but not terribly complex.

On tap, served in a Goose Island goblet glass. Light tan head which dissipates quickly. Light lacing.  Honey gold in tone, very clear. Effervescent and light mouthfeel. Banana & clove flavors, some hops. Seems a bit thin and flat for the style. Much more easy drinking than I expected.

Had a few glasses from tap at Vol de Nuit on 4th St in the West Village recently. Nice dark pour with a decent light brown head. Very sweet and malty, with fruit notes. Relatively thick on the palette. The entire group was switching over to it, so it seems to be a crowd pleaser.

18.7 Oz "Victorian Pint" Bottle: An elegant pour of darkest ruby-purple (basically black) with a huge tan head which dissipates to a nice ring of lacing. Scent is of strawberries and cream, similar to a mixed-berry yogurt aroma I experienced on another dark Imperial. Nice full mouthfeel and big malty chocolate beginning. Moves to charcaol notes in the middle, then rounds out with a clean, pleasantly dry finish. Very good and very smooth for the ABV.

12 oz. Bottle: I have enjoyed the other DFH beers Ive tried previously, so I had high hopes for their stout. Pour is a deep black with a tan head. The first scent is striking- very sour- like sea salt and vinegar potato chips... The initial flavor is also really sour and surprisingly thin. I let it rest a bit and warm up, and it did mellow out. Retains an aftertaste of charred, overdone burnt meat. Disappointing overall.

Had it on draft at Atlantic Chip Shop in Brooklyn. Great beer to go with a heavy plate of fish and chips. Big hop character and maltiness ending with alcohol notes. My friend said "whoah" after drinking it, but I thought it was really good. The alcohol will definitely get you if youre not careful. Curious to try a bottle at home where I can give this beer its due attention.

A cloudy golden yellow pour with a minor head. Strong scent of green tea in there. Not citrusy, which is what Im used to in West Coast IPAs. Flavor is pretty mellow- carbonated and kind of watery. Overall, this IPAs all right, but I want more hop character in it.

tap from the Liberty Heights Tap Room in Brooklyn: nice golden-orange pour with a minimal white head which dissipates quickly with some lacing. Great scents of grapefruit and perhaps a little grass. Taste follows suit with intense hops, citrus and a big bitter kick. Mouthfeel is solid, ending with a pleasing dry finish. Good amount of carbonation. My favorite of the Sixpoint ales I tried.

tap from the Liberty Heights Tap Room in Brooklyn: cloudy reddish-brown color with a mild off-white head which disappears quickly. No noticeable lacing, but perhaps thats because I was drinking it from a plastic cup! Piney hop, doughy yeast and sweet malt aromas. Taste is full and malty at first, then the hops kick in with a nice punch. Bitter in the finish. Went quite well with a sausage and onion pizza.

22 oz.  Bottle: pours a nice bright golden orange color with a big foamy white head -which leaves tons of lacing behind. I have to agree with most everyone else that you should let it warm to experience the full flavors of this beer. First sniffs indicate big-time hops with soapy lavender and sweet grapefruit aromas. As it warms I get some peach and a definite apricot scent. Tasting is just as nice, with a big full goopy fruity sweetness that rolls off the tongue into bitter and then ends with a cleansing, almost puckering astringency. All of the transitions were seamless, and this beer was quite tasty. Ill be having more.

22 oz. Bottle: Oil black opaque color with a thin off-white head and minimal lacing. At first pour, the aroma is sour + milky, reminiscent of mixed berry yogurt. After warming up a little, some sweeter notes come in. Taste is initially sweet, though body is a bit flat and watery- feels like it should be bigger. Charcoal end finishes with a slight sour aftertase. I want more hops.

12 Fl oz. Bottle: Pours a black coffee color with a thick dirty tan head which thins quickly to a thin ring and leaves nice lacing. Aromas of piney hops, chocolate malts, some leather notes and a unique roast peanut scent. The flavor is big chocolaty malts at first followed by a tinge of alcohol and ending on a yummy roasted nut finish. Good mouthfeel overall. The ending is the best-   reminds me of a charcoal-grilled rib eye steak.
beer_name: North Coast Old Rasputin Russian Imperial Stout

review_blob: 12 oz. Bottle: I was really psyched to find a single bottle of this left in the store. Brought it home and was not disappointed. Pours an elegant clear golden orange with a decent white head which leaves some lacing. Strong hoppy aroma of CRAZY citrus. Oranges and lavender all over the place. The taste follows suit in the same citrus hop vein. Incredibly smooth for its alcohol content and certainly enjoyable. Loved it.

22 oz. Bottle: pours opaque amber with a big old off-white head. A lovely hoppy aroma full of flowers and grass. Heavily carbonated with a full-on sweetness which changes to a quick burst of bitter hops. A little bit of soapiness towards the end. The overall light body leaves my mouth feeling clean and fresh afterwards. Pretty refreshing, but not out-of-this-world.

12 Fl oz. dated 2004: pours cloudy brownish-red with a very minimal yellow-beige head which disappears quickly. Heavy malt aroma with some nuttiness, caramel, slight hints of raisin, and a whiskey burn. More than a little port wine going on here. To me the body  is pretty thin with strikingly present carbonation. The moderately sweet taste turns to a strong alcohol burn- also very much like a tawny port, but without the body to support the intensity of flavor. Ends on burnt caramel with a sweet that lingers. Maybe I just dont like barleywines, but I wasnt that into it. Of interest: I accompanied the beer with some salty aged cheese at the end, and for some reason, it became more effervescent and smooth as a result.

12 oz. Bottle: pours a beautiful translucent ruby red with off-white medium sized head which disappears quickly. Some mild lacing. Chocolate, cherry, raisin and slight wheat notes in the nose. Malty chocolate/espresso taste then charcoal with a very smooth finish. The full mouthfeel followed by such a clean ending makes for a solid porter. Yummmm.

12 oz. Bottle: pours a deep dark black with a monster beige-brown head which disipates quickly, leaving some lacing. Aroma is of salty hops and sweet chocolate. First taste shows deep maltiness, followed by the hops and ending in charcoal bitterness. Not unpleasant alcohol warmth in the end. Leaves my mouth coated and altogether pleasant on the palate. Im learning to appreciate stouts more after too many years of sour Guiness, and this is my first Imperial Stout. The hops in this Victory are quite good.

750 mL Bottle: A clear bubbly light orange pour with thick thick thick downy beige head which lasts forever. Significant tailing. Carbonated and then some. Lovely perfume of yeast and citrus. Flavor hits mid-palate quickly with bold raisin notes, then just as quickly dissipates to a mildly bitter end with a touch of spice. Surprisingly dry.

11.2 oz. Bottle: Dense, opaque black color with a thick beige-yellow head. Good initial start flows to chocolate and coffee. Ends smooth, with no bitter lingering. Lasting mouthfeel is watery at first, then pleasant in aftertase.

11.2 oz Bottle: Opaque honey-brown pour with thick white head and some tailing. Head  sticks around for a while. Strong fruit scent with a sour note- definitely sense the dates. Flavor is the same sweet to sour transition with a watery finish. Very little alcohol heaviness for a dubbel. Quite easy-drinking.

11.2 oz. Bottle: Glorious opaque bright golden honey color with a heavy head. Delightfully sweet, spicy nose. Initial hops followed by lots of citrus, esp. lemon. Takes me back to many days drinking Wikse Witte in Holland. Perfect light, refreshing brew for summer.

Bottle: Ho-hum. I was hoping this was going to be some interesting new micro-find and was pretty disappointed. Caramel color with  sediment floaties. Mildly hoppy flavors overpowered by bitterness and a very flat finish. Boring.

beer_brewer_name: Schneider Weisse G. Schneider & Sohn GmbH
review_blob: Bottle: Rich, deep dark brown coffee color, thick foamy yellow head. Spicy wintery aroma complements the initial sweet fruit tastes. Finishes in spice with clove notes. Very nice.

While its not a refined, complex doppelbock or some earthshattering-hop-laden Imperial IPA, it does a decent job complementing the clean, crisp flavors of Vietnamese food. Its a purpose-specific beer and should be judged as such, in the same way that you wouldnt drink Thai iced coffee every day on your morning commute.

12 Fl oz. Bottle: clear golden amber color and frothy white head on pour. To me the nose of this beer is the only thing going for it- pleasantly hoppy and herbal notes. However, the flavor that follows is unremarkable with lingering bitterness.   Much more intersting IPAs are to be found.

22 oz. Bottle: labeled "Bottle Conditioned in 2004." Rich dark amber color with a decent tan head on pouring. Mellow aroma- mainly molasses with sweet yeasty notes, very little spice or citrus. Big malty first impression shifts to quite hoppy finish with a lingering bitter charcoal stout-like aftertaste. Surprised by the hops at the end. Definitely coats the palate. Id like it to finish more smoothly. My mouth feels like I just smoked a cigar.
11.2 Fl oz: Opaque dark caramel color. Good frothy yellow head. Berries and spice scent. Big on palate, malty. Alcohol finish.
